msItem.incipit: ኵሎሙ᎓ ድዉያን᎓ እለ᎓ መጽኡ᎓ ኀበ᎓ ውእቱ᎓ ቤት᎓ እምነ᎓ ቤተ᎓ ልሔም᎓ ወአድያሚሃ᎓ እምድረ᎓ ይሁዳ።
msItem.note: The miracle is not accounted for by

msItem.incipit: ወካዕበ᎓ ንነግረክሙ᎓ መንክረ᎓ ዘጸሐፋ᎓ አባ᎓ ቶማስ᎓ ቀሲስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 116. An account written by priest Tomas as to how an infidel wanted to pierce the image of St. Mary on 21 Ṭǝrr and about the conversion of the latter's servant
Numbered 117. A story about the Jew Tāfoniyā.
Numbered 118. An account of the miracles at the Egyptian church of Ḥārat Zuwāylah.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ንጉሠ᎓ ግብጽ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ሰፍሮን᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 119. Healing of the Egyptian king Safron from a lion's bite, healing of two mad women, etc.

msItem.explicit: ወይቤሎ᎓ ለጳጳስ᎓ ብከኑ᎓ እብነ᎓ ጸዓዳ᎓ ወጽዱለ᎓ ወአምሮ᎓ ትእም
msItem.note: Numbered 120. Miracle of the scribe Damianus from Philippi. According to , the miracle is mutilated.

msItem.incipit: ምንዳቤሆሙ᎓ ለክርስቲያን᎓ ወይእቲ᎓ ረዳኢቶሙ᎓ ለሰማዕት᎓ ወለመላእክት᎓
msItem.note: According to E. Cerulli, the account is acephalous and mutilated at the end; it is a story of a healing of a poor Ethiopian on whose elbow a "horn" grew up. St. Mary appeared to him in a vision (missing in the mabuscript), he prayed to her and the "horn" fell off on the eve of the feast of 21 Gǝnbot

msItem.incipit: እግዚእትነ᎓ ቅድስት᎓ ድንግል᎓ ማርያም᎓ ወላዲተ᎓ አምላክ᎓ ጸሎታ᎓ ወበረከታ᎓ የሀሉ᎓ ምስለ᎓ ኩልነ᎓ ውሉደ᎓ ጥምቀት᎓ ለዓለመ᎓ ዓለም᎓ አሜን።
msItem.note: Indicated by and supplied with number 139, but this is uncertain. According to E. Cerulli, a part in the beginning is missing.
Numbered 140. The miracle of Bishop Philoteus.
Numbered 141.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ዕብራዊ᎓ እምዘመደ᎓ ክቡራን᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 142. While angling, a Jew from Jerusalem was swallowed by a "snake". He was saved three days later, after a prayer to St. Mary. He was baptized in the river of Sāliḥom, was cleansed from leprosy and remained a servant of the church of St. Mary till the end of his life.
Numbered 143. Resurrection of the monk Bārdǝyos from the country of Bānyos, who made a sin while he was on his way to ābbā Yāʿqob and, instigated by Devil, commited suicide.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ካህን᎓ ወቀሲስ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ቂሳርያ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ እንድርያስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 144. A Caesarean presbyter Andrew celebrated the liturgy of St. Mary; the community complained about this to Bishop Dorotheus who first prohibited Andrew to do so, but repented after the apparition of St. Mary.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ደማስቆስ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ አቢፋንዮስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 145. The cobbler Epifanius of Damascus had a daughter Mary who dedicated herself to the Mother of God. Also she made to Her servant the patrician Nifon (Niphontus), or ʾAgābos. He brought Mary to the monastery of Kalamon, made big donations and bequethed himself to be buried there. When he was killed in the oasis ʾElwāḥ, St. Mary appeared to the abbess and ordered her to go to the place of Nifon's death and transport his body to the monastery.

msItem.explicit: ወእሉ᎓ ተጠምቁ᎓ በይእቲ᎓ ዕለት᎓ ምስሌ᎓ ዮሴፍ᎓ አርባዕቱ᎓ ምእት᎓ ነፍስ᎓ እምሰብአ᎓ ቤቱ᎓ ዘእንበለ᎓ እ
msItem.note: Numbered 146. The end is missing.

msItem.incipit: ወይሰቲ᎓ ማየ᎓ ወቀስተሂ᎓ ዘስርግው᎓ በወርቅ᎓ ወእንዘ᎓ የሐውር᎓ ረከበ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ሐረሳዊ᎓
msItem.note: The beginning is missing.

msItem.incipit: ወነበረት᎓ ዐሠርተ᎓ ወከልኤተ᎓ ዓመተ᎓ እንዘ᎓ ትትናዘዝ᎓ እምኀበ᎓ መላእክት᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 123. Healing of an epileptic man to appealed to St. Mary when she was yet at the temple. The identification is uncertain.

msItem.incipit: ወካዕበ᎓ ኮነ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ነጋዲ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ቂሳርያ᎓ ወዝንቱ᎓ አይሁዳዊ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 124. An account of Basil (the Great?) of Caesarea about conversion of a Jewish merchant who stole a golden chalice from a church, and the apparition of St. Mary to him. After the conversion, his name was Sutāy or Šutāy.
Numbered 125. The miracle of a fountain of water caused by Jesus.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩መኰንን᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ነቅስዮስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 126. An account about the birth of St. Minas to the city governor Eudoxius, after his wife prayed in front of the image of St. Mary.
Numbered 127.
Numbered 128. Identification according to no. 22
Numbered 129.
Numbered 130.

msItem.incipit: ዘገብረቶ᎓ እግዝእትነ᎓ ማርያም᎓ ምስለ᎓ ፍቁር᎓ ወልዳ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 131. Identification uncertain.
Numbered 147. According to , 146 (the number?) is missing.

msItem.incipit: ወሀለወት᎓ አሐቲ᎓ ሐመር᎓ ዓቢይ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 148. Pilgrims and Bishop Gregory sailed on the Black Sea in a ship. They were shipwrecked, but a pilgrim who had always adressed St. Mary in his prayers was miraculously saved.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ፍልስጥኤም᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ዮናስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 149. In Palestine, a man called Jonah forsook his wife and went to another woman. The wife prayed in front of an image of St. Mary asking that her rival be afflicted with all kinds of disasters. She saw a dream in which St. Mary told her that her request is not fitting, and that the rival venerates St. Mary as well and attends the church daily. Finally, the rival woman repented and left Jonah.

msItem.incipit: ወኮነ᎓ ልማዶሙ᎓ ለሰብአ᎓ ሮሜ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 150. In Rome, on the day of the Assumption of St. Mary, during a procession, a woman suddenly met her female friend Dinā, a daughter of ʾAwsānyā. She had died, had been resurrected from the dead by St. Mary and released from the Hades where she was placed as punishment for her dissolute behaviour.
Numbered 151.
Numbered 152.
Numbered 153.
Numbered 154.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ባርቶስ᎓ ወልድ᎓ ወሬዛ᎓ ወስሙ᎓ ቆዝሞስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 155. Cosmas of Bārtos (Beirut?) venerated the Mother of God. He went to the monastery on the Mount of Olives and withdrew into a cave. The abbot told him to leave with the community. Cosmas prayed in the night in front of the image of St. Mary, received a call to serve her in a dream, and took the monastic vow.
Numbered 156.
Numbered 157.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ደሴት᎓ መንገለ᎓ ባሕረ᎓ ኢያሪኮ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 158. There was a monastery on an island in the Sea of Iyāriko; one of the nuns venerating the Mother of God fall in love and run away with a priest. After foour years she repented, and St. Mary brought her back into her cell so that the other did not notice, protecting her from the evel tongues.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ሐያቤ᎓ መዓር᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 159. A beekeeper consulted a sorcerer (how to get more honey from the bees); following her advice, he put into a beehive the holy communion that he brought in his mouth.
Numbered 160.
Numbered 161. Miracle of the scribe Damianus from Philippi. (Repeated?).
Numbered 162.
Numbered 163.

msItem.incipit: ወሀለወት᎓ አሐቲ᎓ ብእሲት᎓ ኃጥእት᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 164. A sinful woman wanted to commit suicide and swallowed a scorpion. Suffering from great pain, she put on her breast an image of St. Mary. After that she gave birth to three scorpions, recovered and confessed her sins to archpriest John "according to the law of the Synodos".

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ሲላን᎓ ዘሀገረ᎓ ኢቆንዮስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 165. A vision of the monk Silon in the country of ʾIqonyos: the Mother of God, appearing in the meal time, prevents harm from poor food of the monk, who feed on wild plants.

msItem.incipit: ወሀለወት᎓ አሐቲ᎓ ብእሲት᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ሮሜ᎓ በቤተ᎓ ሶፍያ᎓ ዘስማ᎓ እንባብሬና᎓
msItem.explicit: In Rome, ʾƎnbābrenā lived in the house of Sophia. She had an eye disease, and fastened according to the vow she gave to the Mother of God. The faith of her husband was not big; he forced her to break the fasting. The Mother of God awarded the woman on each and filled her chest with precious jewelry. The woman understood and managed to convince her husband. The chest became enmpty again.
msItem.note: Numbered 166.

msItem.incipit: ወሀለወት᎓ አሐቲ᎓ ብእሲት᎓ ዘስማ᎓ ሶፍያ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 167. Sophia was from a noble Israelite lineage, and her husband was from the "lineage of Aaron". They lived on an island in the Northern Sea. The confessor Mark adviced them to deny the luxury for the sake of the poor. The wife distributed all her jewelries. The husband was angry and did not permit the wife to go to the church on the feast of Presentation of Mary in the Temple, because the clothes of her wife were poor. Then she started to pray at home, and saw the heavenly liturgy in a dream.

msItem.incipit: ወነበረ᎓ ውስተ᎓ ቍስጥንጥንያ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ አቦሊ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 168. A story about the tradesman ʾAboli of Constantinople. He got poor and borrowed money from the Jew Gardān on the date of St. Mary's nativity, having left his son as gage, and went for trade to the shores of the "northern Ṭegros". On the way back, having reached ʾAkko, he realised that he will not be in time for repaying the debt. A delay would cause the enslavement of his son. Having prayed to the Mother of God, ʾAboli threw a box with money and a brief to the Jew into the sea. The Jew received the money but nevertherless he sued ʾAboli. The voice of the Mother of God, who was appealed to be a witness, compelled him to get baptized.
Numbered 169.

msItem.incipit: ወነበረ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ክቡር᎓ ወቡሩክ᎓ ዘይፈርሆ᎓ ለእግዚአብሔር᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ሰርጊስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 170. The wife and the husband broke the vow of virginity and gave birth to a son. Because of the mother's unwary words, the boy was doomed to Satan. He went to Rome where Pope Epiphanius gave him a letter to Bishop Niqonyos of Jerusalem. The latter sent the boy to the monastery of Dabra Qwānṣǝl, to the ascetic Gabra Krǝstos. He entrusted the boy to the Mother of God, who saved him from Hell when Gabra Krǝstos he was celebrating the Mass for him.

msItem.incipit: ወነበረ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ባዕል᎓ ወነጋዲ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ፊልጶስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 171. A rich trader Philipp lived in the city of Niqonyā; he distributed all his possession among the poor. Another trader, Silān, lent him 1,000 golden coins, but Philipp used them for caritative purposes. Silān got angry about this but repented when he saw the Last Judgement at which the Mother of God is trying to save him, referring to the money given for good things.

msItem.incipit: ወሀለዉ᎓ ክልኤቱ᎓ አኃው᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ሮሜ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 173. Two brothers lived in Rome, archdeacon Peter, and Stephan, the governor of the city of ʾƎnṣǝnā. Both were greedy; Stephan robbed the church of St. Sirloryos but celebrated the commemoration of St. Peter the Apostle, and fed the poor on that day. After he died, St. Peter reconciled him with Sirloryos and presented him to the Morther of God, who menaged to get for him a three day resurrection for recompensing the living people whom he offended. Thanks to the prayers of Stephan and Pope Fināḥas, Peter obtain the same chance.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ፈረሳዊ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ማልኮስ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ንሒስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 170. The knight Mālkos of the city of Nǝḥis, being a sinner, celebrated the feasts of St. Mary and Archangel Michael monthly. Later he repented, intended to found a monastery, but died. Archangel Michael and St. Mary saved his soul from demons and returned it into his body. He lived 88 years after that.

msItem.incipit: ወነበረ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ሮሜ᎓ ሊቀ᎓ ጳጳሳት᎓ ዲበ᎓ መንበረ᎓ ጴጥሮስ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ጰኵሚስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 171. Pope Pachomius stole myrrh from his own church and sold it. Apostle Peter threathened him with Gehenna. Pachomius gathered the priests, and one old man said to him that the only way of salvation is to pray to the Mother of God. First the prayers of Peter were rejected, his sin was pardoned only after the third prayer thanks to the mediation of St. Mary. With the money received for myrrh, Pachomius bought a precious stone and decorated an image of the Mother of Got with it.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ቀሲስ᎓ ውስተ᎓ አሐቲ᎓ ሀገር᎓ እምብሔረ᎓ ግብጽ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 172. An account about a greedy Egyptian priest who refused to visit a dying old woman who venerated the Mother of God, and went to a dying money lender instead.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ደብር᎓ ውስተ᎓ አሐቲ᎓ ሀገር᎓ ዘስማ᎓ ደብረ᎓ ምጥማቅ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 173. An account about a nun from the Egyptian monastery of Dabra Mǝṭmāq. She was saved by the Mother of God from a sin with a rich young man, who himself repented, dispersed his possessions and went into a monastery.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ውስተ᎓ ሀገረ᎓ ሮሜ᎓ አመ᎓ መዋዕለ᎓ ንጉሠ᎓ ሳባ᎓ ፈተውኩ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 174. An account about the shepherd Paul of Rome who gave his soul to Devil and was saved in the cathedral of St. Paul, outside of the city.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ በማእከለ᎓ ባሕረ᎓ ጤግሮስ᎓ ደሴት᎓ ዘይሰመይ᎓ ደብረ᎓ ኤፍሬም᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 175. An account the blessed death of a monk who venerated the Mother of God, in a monastery of an island in the river of Tigris.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ፈረሳዊ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ኒፎን᎓ ዘሃገረ᎓ ገላአድ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 176. The knight Nifon of Galāʾad, suffering from an unshared love, recited each day 150 times the Praise of Mary, following an advice of the monk ʾAlāniqos. After a year, while hunting, he found an old church prayed there in front of the image of the Mother of God. He appeared to him; he took on monastic habit, and died one year later.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ናታን᎓ በደብረ᎓ ሰራብዮን᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 177. The knight Natan from the monastery of Seraphion venerated the Mother of God and was asking her to reveal to him her glory. She appeared to him in the midnight, with the Book of Prophet Isaiah in her hand, and let Natan touch one of her cheeks. The next day he was as if he were encharmed; he could not sing in the church and was beaten up for this by the abbot.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ አሐዱ᎓ ነጋዲ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ ጥብርያኖስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 178. An account about the trader Ṭǝbrǝyānos who got impoverished. Devil promised him riches if he would deny his faith. Ṭǝbrǝyānos denied Christ, angels and Baptism, but did not deny the Mother of God, "the queen of the entire world". Devil disappeared and Ṭǝbrǝyānos, after a long prayer on the remains of an old church, saw a dream in which St. Mary was supplicating for him. Ṭǝbrǝyānos woke up and went to take on the monastic habit.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ብእሲ᎓ ኖላዊ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 179. An account about a monastery sheperd who prayed to the Mother of God for saving the cattle from the cold. She appeared to him and announced that his death is coming.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ብእሲ᎓ ወሬዛ᎓ ዘይነብር᎓ ውስተ᎓ አሐቲ᎓ ሀገር᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 180. An account about a poor young man who earned his life selling fire wood. He was awarded with richness for his reverence to the image of the Mother of God that was on the city gates.
Numbered 181.
Numbered 182.
Numbered 183.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ወሬዛ᎓ እመዋዕለ᎓ ተንበላት᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 184. An account about a Muslim who honoured the Mother of God. She converted him into Christianity by Pope Lǝyon. After the deathof the latter he was elected to become pope. During his first liturgy, his former girl friend bit his hand which he cut off. Thanks to the prayer of St. Mary, he got his hand back in "shiny appearance".
Numbered 185.
Numbered 186.
Numbered 187.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ንጉሥ᎓ ዘይነብር᎓ ውስተ᎓ ባሕር᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 188. An account about a prince of an island. He revered an image of St. Mary that was in the church of his house and it conversed with the prince about the necessity to remain virgin. Being compelled to marry by his father, the prince run away from home, acidentally fell and died.

Numbered 189. A version of (the miracle numbered 178) . A young nobleman who lived "in the middle of a sea" and got impoverished, became rich thanks to St. Mary, when a rich man who married his daughter.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ብእሲ᎓ ባዕል᎓ ጥቀ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 190. An account about a woman who was waiting for her lover and reading the book of "the Horologium of St. Mary", but she was prevented from the sin by an apparition of St. Mary.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ብእሲ᎓ ሊቅ᎓ ወባዕል᎓ ጥቀ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 191. An account about a pious nobleman who established a hospital and a homeless shelter. The envious Satan became his assistant and was about to destroy him. The nobleman was saved thanks to the power of a prayer to St. Mary that he was reading daily. The prayer was recorded by a bishop who was passing by; he managed to Satan.

msItem.note: Numbered 195. An account about a woman who had an incestuos relation with her son. She was pardoned thanks to the prayer of the Mother of God.

msItem.incipit: በእንተ᎓ ዘከመ᎓ አስተርአይዎ᎓ ለአባ᎓ ማርዳሪ᎓ ፲፪መላእክት᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 205. ʾAbbā Mārdāri is visited and blessed by 12 angels who were on their way to Constantinople, to listen to John Chrystosom.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ብእሲ᎓ በአሐቲ᎓ ሀገር᎓ ወውእቱሰ᎓ ብእሲ᎓ ባዕል᎓ ውእቱ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 206. Account about the salvation of a richman's estate from pest. The Mother of God appeared as a dove and surpressed the illness with her wings.
Miracles numbered 207, 208, 209.

msItem.incipit: ይቤ᎓ ጳውሎስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 210. Entrupted to the Third Heaven, Paul the Apostle sees the celestial glory of St. Mary.

msItem.incipit: ወኮነ᎓ ሎቱ᎓ ለአባ᎓ አሞኒ᎓ ቅዱስ᎓ ረድእ᎓ ዘስሙ᎓ አባ᎓ ብሖር᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 211. The Mother of God appeared to ʾabbā Bǝḥor, a discple of ʾabbā ʾAmmoni, in a desert, and showed him Christ in the Orient, in a cart with four hourses.

msItem.incipit: ይቤ᎓ ጎርጎርዮስ᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 212. St. Gregory of Armenia sees the celestial glory of St. Mary.
Numbered 213.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ በሀገረ᎓ ኢየሩሳሌም᎓
msItem.note: Numbered 214. In the city of Jerusalem, at a site close to Salem and Jordan where Christ dwelled while he was on flight from Herodes, John brother of Chist appears annually on the 12th of Ḫǝdar, and the Mother of God appears on the 21st of Ṭǝr. The place is hidden from the infidels.

msItem.incipit: ወሀሎ᎓ ፩ንጉሥ᎓ በሀገር᎓ ዘይብልዎ᎓ ሙፃአ᎓ ፀሐይ᎓
msItem.explicit: ዘከመ᎓ አድኅነቶሙ᎓ ወባልሐቶሙ᎓ ለመስርያን᎓ ለአጋንንት᎓ ቅኑያን᎓ እለ᎓ ኢተጠምቁ᎓ በስመ᎓ ወልዳ᎓ ብርሃን። ጸሎታ
msItem.note: Numbered 215. A daugther of the king of "the Land of the Rising Sun" gave birth to the son ʾAwǝr, from the magician ʾAbrāsi. When this was uncovered eight years later, the magician escaped to Faiyum with his two sons, but died there. His children erected a column and lived on it, doing magic. The Mother of God appeared to them and asked what the want. They asked for "the immortality milk". St. Mary ordered Archangel Gabriel to kill them, but thanks to the prayer of ʾAwǝr she had mercy upon them.
